ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: The syllabus really helps learn about melodrama as a specific type of historical performance the melodramatic. I thought each reading built on the other in a really exciting way.
The progression of readings was clear thematically, but sometimes we didn't actually discuss all of the material we read for class.

This course covers both melodrama and its antecendents as a period-distinct genre and the melodramatic as a mode deployed throughout dramatic history. As with all of Jim's courses the syllabus is split into "A" and "B" which provides a comprehensive overview of the subject with ample space for personal exploration.

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: I thought the discussions were really interesting and only got more richer and interesting as the semester went on and we had more shared reading and ideas to throw into the mix. The class on THE OCTOROON in which Branden Jacobs-Jenkins visited might be my favorite class of all time at YSD thus far.
This course strikes a good balance between instruction and discussion.
I have taken several classes with Jim and I think this one generated the most discussion between he and the students and I really enjoyed it.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: Audited class. Maybe can incorporate small presentations a la the Elinor Theory Class one-minute presentations. Or maybe each week one person is in charge of generating one discussion question? What's the best way of encouraging more active participation from students?

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: It was really great to have the two or three plays that everyone was expected to read, but also to have additional resources available if you were interested in exploring more.
On some weeks, the reading load was considerable.
The texts of melodrama tend to be shorter than those found in other courses. This meant that we were able to cover more than one play per class while still giving each sufficient time.
Loved the days were we had one or two plays to discuss. Makes the discussion more involved rather than stretched out.
The variety of videos was so great. It was enlightening to see the melodramatic operate in so many different forms--opera, film, mainstream American movies, etc.

Jim's library of supplementary material is second to none. Each week supplementary materials are passed around the class for perusal. These materials help to ground the work under discussion in a more concrete way.
Jim always provides a treasure-trove of secondary audio and visual materials. They are awesome.

Jim is the king of supplementary materials. We should have to watch more of the materials and discuss them in class. Maybe instead of a play text as the main object of discussion one of the supplementary materials could best be the main object of discussion. How can the extra materials on V2 be required? Or be more active participants in class discussion?

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: Melodrama is essential! It is everywhere, and it has already influenced my work as a critic and dramaturg at YSD.
It would be helpful to have an early class which introduced the key concepts and terms in more depth before continuing on to a discussion of the plays.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: Absolutely! I wish playwrights had the opportunity and/or motivation to take the course.
Yes.
Yes.
Melodrama is one of the most pervasive modes of drama in existence. I would consider it essential training for anyone in the arts or entertainment generally.
Yes, I think the forms and plays we're exposed to in this class are a must for contemporary theatre makers.

If we talked more about the theater craft inventions of Melodrama, perhaps TD&Ps would be interested, but their schedules are insane, so maybe not. What I appreciated about this class the most, though, was the attention to the actual material practice of theater. What a great way of learning the history of our craft!

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: The instructor is excellent at articulating how these plays and ideas work as theater. His enthusiasm and humor also make the class really enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: Jim is constantly open to new points of view and incorporates them into the class.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: Audited

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: Jim is frequently available to meet outside of class.
Jim always makes himself very available to his students

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: ABSOLUTELY!

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: All
ALL
All 14 meetings.
All

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: The course is really exceptional, and the syllabus is a chance to read so many great plays that I might not otherwise have encountered, such as "Girl of the Golden West" and "Black-Ey'd Susan"

The usual response. Less is more. Perhaps less reading and more viewing? More discussion of history , of practice. Of having to make the text a reality on stage. THOSE kinds of questions and historical reconstructions are so, so critical in our field.
